item.title: Much Bigger Battlefield 6 Maps Leak Online Following Datamine
item.content:encoded:
Beauty and the east(wood).

I have good news for Battlefield 6 players concerned about the modest sizes of the open beta maps ‚Äî a new leak suggests at least two more of the as-yet unreleased maps will be bigger than any we've played so far.

Based on recent datamines, Battlefield Wire shared an image, below, showing the purported size of two maps ‚Äî Eastwood and Mirak Valley ‚Äî in relation to the beta map Siege of Cairo. And you don't have to get out a measuring tape and ruler to see that they're considerably bigger (albeit still a little on the snug side for some).

Here are the borders of two of the larger maps coming to Battlefield 6 üëÄ

The largest being ‚ÄòMirak Valley‚Äô

Via: 1BF pic.twitter.com/RFCKuyKVnx

‚Äî Battlefield Wire (@TheBFWire) August 16, 2025

MP1st has also shared renderings that an anonymous poster has uploaded to Imgur. They give us a closer look at Mirak Valley ‚Äî a map located in Tajikistan with mountains and a river slicing through the middle ‚Äî and Californian map Eastwood, which is supposedly coming post-launch, but likely sometime in Season 1. Expect to see a golf course, villas, and bonus vehicles like a boat and a golf cart. You can check out all the renderings for Eastwood here, and Mirak here.

This should be excellent news for players unimpressed by Battlefield 6's beta map offerings thus far, and whilst we can only take datamined rumors as precisely that ‚Äî rumors ‚Äî it bolsters DICE's claim that "large maps exist, and the tempo scales accordingly, you'll be able to see soon enough!"

Last week, EA issued a statement acknowledging the cheating occurring in Battlefield 6, and highlighting its efforts to combat it on top of its requirement for players to enable Secure Boot in their BIOS. In the post, the publisher said its existing tech had already prevented 330,000 attempts to cheat or tamper with anti-cheat controls. EA said it would continue to evolve its efforts to combat cheating, and encouraged users to continue reporting issues.

DICE made changes to Rush mode after a negative response from fans, but generally the Battlefield 6 open beta has gone down well, with huge concurrent figures on Steam. It suggests a massive launch for the game when it comes out in October.

item.title: Everything Announced at the 2025 Pok√©mon World Championships
item.content:encoded:
The 2025 Pok√©mon World Championships just concluded, and as is tradition, the closing ceremonies featured new announcements fun for Pok√©mon fans of all kinds, presented by Tzunekazu Ishihara, President and CEO of The Pok√©mon Company. Here‚Äôs a round-up of all the important Pok√©mon announcements revealed at the World Championships you don‚Äôt want to miss, including the introduction of a new fan event called Pok√©monXP, and much more.

Pok√©mon Champions Coming to the 2026 Pok√©mon World Championships

The yet-to-be-released Pok√©mon Champions, coming to mobile and Nintendo Switch in 2026, will be the game used in the official Championship Series video game format in 2026 and beyond. Read more about how Pok√©mon Champions will be replacing Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet in the official format here.

Empoleon, Dhelmise, and Vaporeon Joining the Pok√©mon Unite Roster

Empoleon will be coming to Pok√©mon Unite as a playable character on September 19, while Dhelmise and Vaporeon are ‚Äúcoming soon.‚Äù No word on what roles the three new Pok√©mon will be.

Starting on September 4, Groudon will be taking over for Rayquaza at the Theia Sky Ruins in the final two-minute stretch of the game. Defeating Groudon will give you a ‚Äúmassive Attack boost and goal-scoring speed increase.‚Äù But if the opposing team knocks you out, they'll steal the buff from you!

Mega Evolution Coming to Pok√©mon Trading Card Game Pocket

A new season is coming to Pok√©mon TCG Pocket this fall, and with it, the debut of Mega Pok√©mon, including Mega Altaria, Mega Gyarados, Mega Blaziken and more Mega Evolution Pok√©mon ex.

Legendary Pok√©mon Eternamax Eternatus Makes its Global Pok√©mon GO Debut

Eternamax Eternatus began appearing in the Anaheim, CA right after the Pok√©mon World Championships concluded, but that won‚Äôt be the only chance for GO players to get their hands on this rare Pok√©mon. The Pok√©mon GO: Dark Skies event will take place from August 18-23, 2025, with the Max Finale taking place between August 23-25, 2025. During the unticketed event, which can be joined from anywhere in the world with the free GO Pass: Max Finale, players will be able to catch every Dynamax and Gigantamax Pok√©mon that has appeared so far, plus Eternatus.

Mega Charizard X and More Returning to Pok√©mon TCG

We got a sneak peek of some new cards featuring Mega Evolution Pok√©mon and cool full-art cards during the closing ceremonies, including for Mega Charizard X ex, Mega Gardevoir ex, and Mega Lucario ex. Though not a ‚Äúmega‚Äù itself, Oricorio ex was also revealed, which has a unique Ability called Excited Turb: As often as you like during your turn, if you have any Fire-type Mega Evolution Pok√©mon ex in play, you may use this Ability. Attach a Basic Fire-type Energy card from your hand to one of your benched Fire-type Pok√©mon.‚Äù

We also got a look at a new, adorable Mega Dragonite ex card, but not the full-art version just yet! Its Ability Sky Transport will allow you to switch your Active Pok√©mon with one of your Benched Pok√©mon.

4-Player Ranked Battles Coming to Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A

Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A Screenshots

The latest trailer shown durin the Pok√©mon World Championship closing ceremonies featured a breakdown of Z-A Battle Club‚Äôs four-player Ranked Battles. We saw in the trailer four trainers battling at once, being able to take down multiple Pok√©mon at once with powerful, well-timed AOE attacks‚Äìlike Draco Meteor. The goal is to get the most knockouts you can before the three-minute timer is up, and don‚Äôt worry, you can rejoin after one of your Pok√©mon faints! These real-time Link Battles! can be played locally or online against other players. Read our hands-on impressions of the Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A battle system.

Pok√©monXP, a New Pok√©mon Fan Experience, Coming to San Francisco

2025 Pok√©mon World Championships Exclusive Merch Reveal

We already knew the 2026 Pok√©mon World Championships were coming to San Francisco, but so is Pok√©monXP, a new ‚Äúevent that celebrates all things Pok√©mon‚Äù with ‚Äúa range of Pok√©mon-centric festivities.‚Äù It will take place August 28-30, 2026, overlapping with the 2026 Pok√©mon World Championships, at the Moscone Center in downtown San Francisco. Passes will go on sale September 17, 2025 and start at $120 USD for a multi-day pass for adults and $70 USD for youth under 18.

There are two different multi-day passes. The regular one, and multi-day + arena pass, which includes normal access to the Pok√©monXP event, plus access to the arena on Championship Sunday. Read all about the Pok√©monXP event here.

2026 Championship Sunday Taking Place at Chase Center in San Francisco

This year, The Pok√©mon World Championships hosted Championship Sunday in an arena for the first time, and in 2026, they‚Äôre upscaling it even more, bringing Championship Sunday to the massive Chase Center, which has a seating capacity of 18,064 (at least, for basketball games.) Compare that to the Anaheim Convention Center Arena, with a capacity of 7,500. Which, I heard, was filled to capacity this year!

IGN was at the Pok√©mon World Championships in Anaheim this year, where we watched 2025 Pokemon World VGC Champion Kevin Han make history, and played a first-ever demo of Pokemon Legends: Z-A.

Casey DeFreitas is a deputy editor on the guides team at IGN and this year is the second time she's covered the Pok√©mon World Championships in Anaheim, CA. Catch her on socials @ShinyCaseyD.

item.title: Pok√©mon Champions will Replace Scarlet and Violet at the Pok√©mon World Championships Next Year
item.content:encoded:
In a Pok√©mon World Championship Series first, the 2026 and future formats will be using yet-to-be-released Pok√©mon Champions as the game for VGC competitors instead of a "mainline" game. To switch up the format even more next year, Pok√©mon Champions will include the Mega Evolution mechanic in the official format.

Usually, players compete in fierce Pok√©mon battles throughout the year for a spot at the Pok√©mon World Championships using the most recent "core," or "mainline" Pok√©mon game, like Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, or Pok√©mon Sword and Shield before that.

Pok√©mon Champions isn't a self-contained narrative game, but rather a new, multiplayer battle-focused Pok√©mon game coming to both mobile and Nintendo Switch. It features a simplified training system, which should make competitive battling more accessible than ever. It will also have compatibility with Pok√©mon Home, allowing trainers to transfer legacy Pok√©mon from other games. We're unsure which Pok√©mon from what games will be legal to use in next year's format.

Pok√©mon Champions features "core-style battles" with gimmicks from all eras of Pok√©mon, including Mega Evolution, originally from Pok√©mon X and Y, and Terastalization, from the recent Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet. So far, we know that Mega Evolution will return in Ranked Battles in this year's official format. Mega Dragonite, recently revealed in a Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A Trailer, will also be coming to Pok√©mon Champions.

Pok√©mon Champions is set to be released in 2026 and is being developed by Game Freak in collaboration with The Pok√©mon Works. Players usually begin competing for Championship Points soon after the previous year's World Championships, so we've yet to see how the release date will affect tournaments for this year's format.

This is a year of many firsts for the Pokemon World Championships. VGC Champion Kevin Han made history by taking the championship title in the Junior and then Senior divisions in back-to-back years, and it's the first time Championship Sunday was held in an arena. Next year, the 2026 Pokemon World Championships' Championship Sunday will be held at the Chase Arena in San Francisco. Don't miss all of the announcements from the 2025 Pokemon World Championships.

Casey DeFreitas is a deputy editor on the guides team at IGN and this year is the second time she's covered the Pok√©mon World Championships in Anaheim, CA. Catch her on socials @ShinyCaseyD.

item.title: 2025 Pok√©mon Worlds VGC Champion Kevin Han Achieves Historic First
item.content:encoded:
Kevin Han just won back-to-back Pok√©mon World Championships in two divisions.

Pok√©mon World Championships competitor Kevin Han just won the 2025 Video Game Seniors World Champion title in Anaheim, CA, making him the first to win the VGC Pok√©mon World Championships in both the Junior and Senior age divisions. To make this achievement even more impressive, Han took these titles back-to-back, and this year, with a completely undefeated record.

‚ÄúI have no words to describe it. It‚Äôs an unreal feeling, I still can‚Äôt believe it,‚Äù Han said after being asked about his unprecedented achievement.

Han, a 12-year-old from Pennsylvania, US, faced Sian Lee from South Korea in the Senior division finals. Last year, Han was defeated only twice during his climb to the Junior Championship title, and one of those defeats was at the hands of Lee, making this finals match-up especially nerve-racking.

Before the match, Han‚Äôs brother, Chris Han, was asked about how Kevin Han was feeling.
‚ÄúI can tell you one thing, he‚Äôs super nervous‚Ä¶ but Kevin‚Äôs got this,‚Äù Chris Han said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any words of advice, just trust your gut Kevin‚Äìyou know exactly what to do.‚Äù

Chris Han‚Äôs faith in his brother rang true, as Kevin Han won 2-0.

‚ÄúI think after turn one of each game, where I got my positioning up, I think I felt a lot better,‚Äù Kevin Han said. ‚ÄúSometimes if you‚Äôre too nervous it can hurt you, but, in my opinion, having at least a little bit of nerves can help you a lot.‚Äù

Kevin Han secured his victory in the second match with a Double K.O. with his Ice Rider Calyrex‚Äôs Glacial Lance, super effective on Lee‚Äôs Rillaboom and just powerful enough to finish off the previously-damaged Zamazenta.

Ray Rizzo is the only previous Pok√©mon competitor to have won the VGC Championship in two divisions: the Senior division in 2010, then the Master division in 2011. This makes Kevin Han the first-ever contender with the ability to take the World Championship title in all three divisions: Juniors, Seniors, and Masters. We‚Äôll have to wait three years before he ages into the Masters division, where he just might make history yet again.

Kevin Han‚Äôs win isn‚Äôt the only historical first at this year‚Äôs Pok√©mon World Championships. This is also the first ever time Championship Sunday was held in a dedicated arena rather than on the stage on the convention center floor.
